summary: The content discusses various incentives and policies related to electric vehicles (EVs) and battery startups, focusing on different regions and vehicle categories. It includes details on demand-side incentives, early bird incentives, and supply-side incentives for charging infrastructure. Specific policies for Jharkhand and Punjab are highlighted, including objectives, validity periods, and specific incentives for different types of EVs and charging stations.

The article discusses the global trend in venture capital funding for electric vehicles (EVs) and battery startups. It highlights that while there was a significant boom in VC investments in the past decade, the latest Global EV Outlook 2024 report by the International Energy Agency indicates a substantial drop in 2023. Factors contributing to this drop include geopolitical tensions, supply chain disruptions, high energy prices, and rising inflation and interest rates. Despite the overall decline, certain segments such as EV charging technology and battery recycling saw notable investments. India emerged as a significant player in the global VC market for EVs, particularly in the 2/3-wheeler segment.

The Delhi EV Policy aims to improve air quality by deploying 25% of all new vehicles as battery-operated by 2024. It provides various demand-side incentives for different EV segments, including electric two-wheelers, e-autos, e-rickshaws, e-carts, e-buses, and goods carriers. Supply-side incentives include grants for EV charging infrastructure and additional policies for aggregator EVs, bicycle incentives, and retrofitting guidelines.

The Assam Electric Vehicle Policy 2021 aims to create an ecosystem for manufacturing EV components in Assam and promote the adoption of electric mobility. It provides demand-side incentives based on battery capacity and supply-side incentives for charging infrastructure and EV manufacturers. The policy is valid from 2021 to 2025.

The Andhra Pradesh Electric Mobility Policy aims to become a leading state in the electric vehicles field by 2029 and a global destination by 2050. It offers various capital subsidies, tax incentives, skill development incentives, and financial incentives for private EV charging stations and hydrogen generation infrastructure. The policy is valid from 2018 to 2023.

The Arunachal Pradesh EV Policy aims to facilitate the adoption of Electric Vehicles by ensuring safe, reliable, and affordable charging infrastructure. It provides demand-side incentives for the first 200 electric vehicles and charging infrastructure subsidies for retail outlets of oil marketing companies and local entrepreneurs. The policy is valid until it is replaced, modified, or denotified.

The Ladakh EV Policy aims to promote sustainable mobility by kickstarting the sale and use of EVs and encouraging research, innovation, and skill development in EV technology. It provides demand-side incentives for the first 200 electric vehicles and charging infrastructure subsidies for retail outlets of oil marketing companies and local entrepreneurs. The policy is valid until it is replaced, modified, or denotified.

The content discusses venture capital funding in electric vehicles (EVs) and battery startups, mapping global trends. It includes details on demand-side incentives for various vehicle segments, such as two-wheelers, three-wheelers, cars, buses, and commercial vehicles, with specific subsidies and maximum ex-showroom prices to avail the incentives. Early bird incentives are also mentioned, providing higher subsidies for a limited number of EVs. Charging infrastructure subsidies and supply-side incentives are also detailed.

Chhattisgarh's EV policy aims to have 15% of new vehicle registrations as EVs by 2027, with a target to procure 4 lakh electric vehicles by 2026-27. The policy includes demand-side incentives such as subsidies for purchasing EVs, waivers on registration fees, and road tax exemptions. Supply-side incentives include grants for EV manufacturing, land allocation for EV parks, and SGST reimbursements. The policy also supports charging infrastructure with capital subsidies and SGST reimbursements.

Chandigarh's EV policy aims to achieve 80% of new vehicle registrations as EVs by the end of the policy period. It includes objectives such as installing 100 charging stations, establishing a wide network of charging points, and promoting the use of electric bicycles. The policy also focuses on leveraging renewable energy sources for EV charging, enabling fleet operators to transition to zero-emission vehicles, and nurturing skill development and R&D in the electric mobility space.

The Punjab EV Policy provides various incentives for electric two-wheelers, three-wheelers, and four-wheelers. Key points include 100% waiver on permit fees and motor vehicle tax for vehicles manufactured in Punjab, with the waiver applicable for 10 years. Fleet and delivery companies are encouraged to transition to electric vehicles in target cities. E-autos and e-rickshaws have specific incentives, including free registration and permit fee waivers. Goods carrier 3Ws and electric buses also receive significant support, with a focus on replacing diesel-based vehicles with electric ones. The policy aims to increase the share of e-taxis and promote the use of e-LCVs for goods carriage.

The Haryana Electric Vehicle Policy aims to promote clean transport and environmental sustainability by reducing pollution and creating an ecosystem for EV manufacturing. Key initiatives include the development of Electric Mobility Industrial Parks with plug-and-play infrastructure, support for manufacturing firms with land, water, and road connectivity, and financial support through capital subsidies. The policy also focuses on EV charging infrastructure, mandating charging stations at depots, bus terminals, public parking spaces, petrol pumps, and government buildings.

The Kerala Electric Vehicle Policy aims to promote shared mobility and clean transportation, reduce pollution, and create an ecosystem for manufacturing EV components. Key objectives include setting up charging stations in major cities and on highways, with a focus on initial pilot districts. The policy also includes a public portal for subsidy applications and the implementation of Time of the Day (ToD) tariff for public charging stations.

The West Bengal Electric Vehicle Policy aims to build a sustainable transportation infrastructure by promoting the Electric Mobility Ecosystem. Key objectives include setting a target of 10 lakh electric vehicles and 1,00,000 public/semi-public charging stations. The policy also focuses on innovation through grants and venture funds, creating a robust infrastructure for EVs, and promoting the recycling and disposal of used batteries in an environmentally friendly manner.

The Uttar Pradesh EV Policy aims to promote sustainable and clean mobility solutions, making the state a global hub for electric mobility development and manufacturing. It offers various incentives including registration fees and road tax exemptions, purchase subsidies, and capital subsidies for charging and battery swapping infrastructure. The policy is valid from 2022 to 2027.

The Uttarakhand EV Policy aims to make the state a preferred destination for EV manufacturing, create employment opportunities, and encourage the use of hybrid EVs. It offers incentives such as interest subsidies, electricity duty exemptions, EPF reimbursement, and stamp duty exemptions. The policy is valid from 2018 to 2023.

The Telangana EV Policy aims to make the state a hub for Electric Vehicles and Energy Storage Systems. It offers demand-side incentives such as road tax and registration fee exemptions for various types of electric vehicles, including two-wheelers, three-wheelers, and buses. Supply-side incentives include capital investment subsidies, SGST reimbursement, power tariff discounts, and electricity duty exemptions. The policy is valid until 2030.

The content discusses various incentives and policies for electric vehicles (EVs) and related infrastructure in Karnataka. It includes details on tax exemptions, registration fees, parking costs, and other benefits for different types of electric vehicles such as E-Auto Rickshaws, E-Goods Carriers, E-Four Wheelers, and E-Buses. Additionally, it outlines supply-side incentives for public EV charging stations, including capital subsidies and other support measures.

The Karnataka EV Policy aims to establish the state as a preferred investment destination for electric vehicle manufacturing. The policy is valid from 2017 to 2022 or until a new policy is announced. It includes objectives to leverage benefits and opportunities for the growth of the EV segment. The public portal for more information is provided.

The policy outlines various supply-side incentives for EV charging infrastructure, including the development of charging stations as commercially viable ventures. It encourages private investment and adherence to BIS standards. Measures include providing land for charging stations, setting up a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) for infrastructure creation, and offering investment subsidies. The policy also supports the use of renewable energy and encourages battery swapping infrastructure.

The policy provides incentives for EV and components manufacturing enterprises, including investment promotion subsidies, exemption from stamp duty, concessional registration charges, reimbursement of land conversion fees, and subsidies for setting up effluent treatment plants. These incentives are aimed at promoting the growth of micro, small, medium, and large enterprises in the EV sector.

The Rajasthan EV policy aims to reduce pollution from diesel and petrol vehicles. It offers subsidies for electric two-wheelers and other electric vehicles based on battery capacity. The policy is valid from April 2021 to March 2022.

The Odisha EV policy aims to accelerate the adoption of EVs, especially two-wheelers, three-wheelers, and light motor vehicles, with a target of 20% of all vehicle registrations being EVs by 2025. It provides purchase incentives and support for electric buses and charging infrastructure.

The Meghalaya EV policy aims to facilitate the adoption of at least 15% EVs by 2025. It offers purchase subsidies for various types of electric vehicles and supports the development of charging infrastructure and startups in the EV ecosystem.

The Maharashtra EV policy aims to increase market demand for EVs and support their adaptability in public and private transport sectors. It offers demand incentives for various vehicle segments and supports the development of charging infrastructure and scrappage incentives.

The Madhya Pradesh EV policy aims to promote sustainable electric mobility and improve air quality by reducing emissions from the transport sector. It offers demand side incentives for electric two-wheelers and e-rickshaws, including tax exemptions and parking fee waivers.

The content discusses various government policies and incentives for electric vehicle (EV) battery manufacturing and assembly enterprises in different states of India. It includes details on investment subsidies, stamp duty exemptions, registration charges, land conversion fees, electricity duty exemptions, and other support measures for EV-related industries in states like Karnataka, Gujarat, Bihar, Goa, and Tamil Nadu.

The Gujarat State EV Policy 2021 aims to support the electrification of 200,000 vehicles and 250 charging stations over four years, making Gujarat a manufacturing hub for electric vehicles and ancillary equipment. It encourages start-ups and investment in electric mobility and associated sectors. The policy provides demand-side incentives for different vehicle segments and supply-side incentives for EV charging infrastructure and manufacturing.

The Bihar EV Policy 2020 aims to create a manufacturing ecosystem for e-vehicles, fulfill Sustainable Development Goals, and make Bihar a preferred investment destination for the EV sector. It offers incentives for the first 100,000 vehicles manufactured within Bihar, including subsidies for electric rickshaws, e-2 wheelers, and e-buses. The policy also provides support for EV manufacturers, EV components, and charging infrastructure.

The Goa EV Policy aims to position Goa as a model for electric vehicle adoption, with 30% of annual vehicles registered in Goa being electric by 2025. It includes objectives to convert 50% of all ferries to electric by 2025, create jobs, encourage start-ups, and promote R&D and skill development in the EV sector. The policy provides demand-side incentives for electric two-wheelers, auto rickshaws, rickshaws, e-carts, and four-wheelers, as well as supply-side incentives for EV manufacturers and charging infrastructure.

The Tamil Nadu EV Policy aims to attract ₹50,000 crore of investment in EV manufacturing and create a comprehensive EV ecosystem. It includes objectives to electrify buses, convert auto-rickshaws to EVs, and provide demand-side and supply-side incentives for various EV segments. The policy also supports the creation of EV vendor parks, free trade warehousing zones, and charging stations.
